title: How can i collect from someone that has filed chapter 7?
question: i was rear ended on 8/2/08. by a 21 year old female who said she didnt have a good job. i sued and won the case in amount of $6130 on 5/12/09. I never received payment. On 8/27/09 i filed a DL-30. Still have not received payment. Today 5/3/10 I received a letter stating that defendant has filed Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. What can i do now to be able to collect from this girl.
answers:
If there are assets in the debtor's estate, you will receive notice to file a proof of claim that will entitle you to a distribution depending upon the size of the estate, and your priority relative to other creditors. You can still pursue debtor's insurance, if any. Finally, depending on the circumstances of the accident, if it was willful and malicous, or caused by a driver that was impaired by alcohol or drugs, your full claim would survive bankruptcy if you brought a claim for nondischargeability. It would be a good idea to consult counsel regarding these issues. Good luck.

After the Chapter 7 case was filed a chapter 7 trustee would have been appointed by the Court. The trustee is responsible for collecting the assets of the debtor, if any (subject to exemptions, which the debtor is allowed to keep).

The Chapter 7 trustee will then distribute the assets to the debtor's creditors based on a priority scheme in the bankruptcy code. If there are not enough assets creditors will not be paid in full (or at all depending on the amount of assets). In a chapter 7 case, to be entitled to receive distributions a creditor must timely file with the Court what is called a proof of claim form and include sufficient information to support the claim. The deadline will be set by the court and there should be notice provided to known creditors as to the deadline and a proof of claim form might also be included (if the trustee believes there are no assets then a proof of claim form will not need to be filed because there are no assets to distribute). A form proof of claim can be found at the following link.
http://www.uscourts.gov/rules/BK_Forms_Official_2010/B_010_0410.pdf

In addition to protecting the claim in bankruptcy court, if there is insurance available a creditor can also file (or find local counsel) a motion to lift the automatic stay to proceed to collect from insurance.
